To accomplish this, we combine kinematic information from Gaia for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages, carefully corrected for systematic errors. By examining their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion, we identify clusters with a shared origin. Our results indicate that approximately 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a vital step in many dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces Intrinsic, an R package that offers innovative, state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for this purpose. Specifically, the package includes the two-nn, gridE, and Hidalgo models. To facilitate use of these cutting-edge estimators, Intrinsic provides several high-level, user-friendly functions that leverage a comprehensive set of efficient, low-level routines. The package covers two main types of intrinsic dimension estimators: homogeneous and heterogeneous. The former group comprises the two-nn and gridE models, for which inference can be performed within both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks using dedicated functions. Conversely, Hidalgo—a Bayesian mixture model—is covered by an effective Gibbs sampler.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrent behavior at the nanosecond scale, which holds great promise for enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems, based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), were proposed and modeled to tackle image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction tasks. Our micromagnetic simulations revealed that an RC system utilizing a single MSM demonstrates exceptional performance in recognizing handwritten digits, while a physical RC system composed of 24 STNOs can effectively solve complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems, as demonstrated in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a vital role in various online platforms, including search engines and recommendation systems. In this study, we reveal a fascinating phenomenon resulting from popularity-based rankings: the less numerous the items reporting a particular signal, the greater the combined traffic they attract. This "few-get-richer" effect materializes in environments with limited item diversity (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news sources) and popularity-based ranking. Through analytical and simulation-based experiments, we investigate how user preferences and ranking mechanisms impact the effect's intensity. Additionally, we conduct real-world tests with human participants to validate our predictions. These insights bear significant consequences for understanding the propagation of false information.

Weight pruning has gained widespread recognition as a simple yet powerful technique for eliminating redundant neurons in deep neural networks (DNNs) and thus accelerating their execution across diverse platforms. Nonetheless, many existing pruning methods involve compromising between model precision and regularization, ultimately leading to diminished inference accuracy and limited acceleration on devices. To address this challenge, we propose introducing a novel sparsity dimension, dubbed pattern-based sparsity, encompassing both pattern and connectivity sparsity. By incorporating carefully crafted patterns, our innovative pruning approach consistently attains unparalleled accuracy enhancements and superior feature extraction capabilities across varied DNN architectures and datasets, while our pattern-aware pruning framework additionally enables pattern library generation, pattern selection, connectivity pruning, and weight training in a single, simultaneous process. Notably, our method seamlessly integrates with compiler optimizations for highly efficient DNN execution on resource-constrained mobile devices.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that significantly diverges from the treated group is susceptible to bias stemming from historical events that differentially affect the groups. Creating a more comparable control group by matching a subset of the total control group to the treated group can help minimize bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. Specifically, we employ a difference-in-differences approach utilizing the surge in mrm following the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments to estimate the impact of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality rates. Our findings indicate a 95% confidence interval that encompasses noteworthy adverse consequences alongside negligible and modest beneficial effects, after constructing a more tightly matched control group for the difference-in-differences analysis of mrm's effect on mortality.

When developing models to summarize clinical data for simulation purposes, it is advisable to assess their ability to replicate the original data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (VPCs), a process consisting of three steps: (1) generating multiple simulations of the original study using the model being evaluated, (2) computing estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of these estimates with the actual estimate from the original study. This approach is a versatile and straightforward method that can be applied generally. In this context, we discuss its application to time-to-event data, specifically addressing the scenario where a time-varying covariate is either unknown or cannot be adequately approximated post-event.

Novel approaches, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems using sequential schemes are presented. We explore how comparable protocols, which rely on both repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can enable us to: (i) mitigate the effects of decoherence on quantum dynamics in line with Zeno's physics. (ii) accurately predict the probability of transferring a quantum system to a desired quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) efficiently reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalising their filter functions in the frequency domain, tailoring them to our designed quantum sensor. Accomplishing these goals will significantly enhance our ability to study and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technology.

Palms sweating, heart pounding, stomach twisting into knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat constricted, making breathing difficult, but it would also be mortifying. No, you're not being pursued by a monster; you're giving a speech, a prospect some consider more terrifying than death. Indeed, when you're deceased, you experience no emotions; at a lectern, you encounter stage fright. However, since humans are inherently social creatures, we must confront this fear eventually. To begin, let's define stage fright. Our concern for our reputation makes us anxious about public speaking, which may tarnish it. Prior to a presentation, we agonize over the possibility of others thinking, "What if they believe I'm unskilled and foolish?"

I can't think of anyone who has only one interest in life and wants to pursue it exclusively forever. Interestingly, around 15% of American workers don't have traditional full-time employment. Instead, they work part-time, temporarily, or on contract. The term "side hustle" aligns well with this trend, as people combine various endeavors to earn a living. The origins of "side hustle" can be traced back to African American newspapers from the 1920s, which initially used "hustle" to describe a swindle. By the 1950s, the phrase had evolved to encompass legitimate work as well. Notably, a side hustle differs slightly from a secondary job, which typically stems from financial necessities rather than personal preferences.

Barabas, the wealthiest dude in Malta, had it all - wealth, power, and a sweet pad. But then, out of nowhere, those pesky Turkish ships rolled in, demanding their share of the loot. And just like that, Barabas was stripped of everything he owned. Talk about a major bummer, right? Well, Barabas wasn't having it. He was determined to take down the Maltese governor who had wronged him. And what better way to do that than to enlist the help of his beautiful daughter, Abigail? Together, they schemed and plotted until they managed to recover some of Barabas' stolen assets. Oh, and they also bought themselves a Turkish slave named Ithamore, who seemed to have a serious grudge against Christians. Like, seriously, this guy hated them with a passion. Anyway, long story short, Barabas used Abigail's charm to manipulate the governor's son, Lodowick, and his BFF Mathias into falling out with each other. It was like a real-life Game of Thrones scenario, minus the dragons and stuff. The two guys ended up battling it out in a fierce duel, and spoiler alert: neither of them made it out alive. OMG, talk about drama! #Tragedy #Revenge #MaltaDrama

Lizzie headed down to the brook to grab some grub from the goblins. They were always selling fresh produce, and she needed some serious snacks. When she got there, they greeted her warmly and asked her to join 'em for a bite. But when they realized she was trying to pay with a few silvers instead of haggling, they got all up in her face. Like, seriously? Who does that? Goblins ain't exactly known for being generous, but this was just ridiculous. They started beating on her, and poor Lizzie had to book it outta there. She made it back home, battered and bruised, but still clutching onto those precious goblin fruits. Her sis Laura wasn't having it though - she refused to touch that weird pulpy stuff. Good thing too, since she ended up transforming into something straight outta a horror movie. Not cool, man. Now both Lizzie and Laura are stuck telling their kids about the time they almost got killed by goblins over some bad fruit. #GoblinFruitFiasco #StayAwayFromTheBrook #SisterlyLove

Domino Harvey, a former model living in LA, became a bounty hunter after getting kicked out of college. She saw a newspaper ad for a bounty hunter training seminar and thought, "Why not? Sounds kinda cool." Her colleagues were Ed Moseby, Choco, and Afghan driver Alf. They worked for Claremont Williams III, a bail bondsman who also ran an armored car business. Claremont's mistress, Lateesha Rodriguez, worked at the California Department of Motor Vehicles. Her granddaughter Mica had a blood disease and needed an operation that cost $300,000. Claremont set up the robbery of $10 million...but little did they know, Domino had a secret talent for hacking and decided to take matters into her own hands. #BountyHunterLife #RobberyGoneWrong #LAAdventures

Gale and Evelle rolled up to the bank in their beat-up old car, Junior squirming in the back seat. They had been planning this heist for weeks, ever since they got outta prison. Nathan Arizona Sr. caught sight of 'em and sauntered over, but Gale and Evelle weren't having it. They knew Small was the one who could help 'em get Junior back, but they didn't trust him as far as they could throw him. When Small finally showed up, Gale and Evelle pounced. They demanded he hand over Junior, but Small started yapping about how he had a better plan. He wanted to kidnap the little guy and hold him for ransom. That's when things went sideways. One of the bank's security canisters blew its top, covering Small in dye. Gale and Evelle grabbed Junior and booked it outta there, leaving Small to deal with the mess. They met up with Nathan Jr. later that night, and he was none the wiser. They figured it was best to keep the whole thing under wraps, so they never told the cops what went down. But hey, that's life in the fast lane, right? You gotta do what you gotta do sometimes. 🤷‍♂️

Truman Capote's fascination with Perry Smith is pretty intriguing. I mean, this dude was a well-known author, and he's got this essay "In Cold Blood" that's basically a true story about the Clutter family. But what caught my attention was why he became so attached to Perry Smith. Like, seriously, what was it about this guy that made Capote go all in? So, from what I gather, Capote was blown away by how detailed Perry Smith was when describing the crime. It was like he had all these secrets hidden behind bars, and only Capote could uncover them. And let's be real, who doesn't love a good mystery, right? So Capote starts digging deeper, talking to Perry Smith, trying to figure out what really went down. But here's where things get interesting. As Capote learns more about Perry Smith's life and the events leading up to the crime, he starts feeling... something. Maybe it's empathy, maybe it's curiosity, or maybe it's just plain old human connection. Whatever it is, it makes Capote want to know more. He's like a detective searching for clues, except instead of solving a murder, he's trying to solve the puzzle that is Perry Smith. Now, I'm not saying Capote fell in love with Perry Smith or anything (although who knows, maybe he did). But there's definitely something there, some kind of bond that forms between them. And that's what makes their story so darn compelling. It's not just about the crime; it's about the people involved and how they affect each other. Anyway, that's my two cents on Truman Capote and Perry Smith. Pretty wild stuff, if you ask me. #TrueCrime #InColdBlood #CapoteVibes

Bateman is seriously ticked off about Paul Allen's business card. Like, who does this guy think he is? A big shot investment banker just because he works with Bateman? Please. Bateman's got skills, ya hear me? He could totally take down Paul Allen if he wanted to. Oh wait, he already did...accidentally, of course. Oops. #InvestmentBankingDrama #CoWorkerBeef #MurderPlotTwist So yeah, Bateman's got a bit of a temper. And when he sees Paul Allen's fancy schmancy business card, he just loses it. Like, how dare he have a higher profile than Bateman? Doesn't he know who Bateman is? #SaltyBateman #JealousMuch And then there's this homeless dude and his dog. They're just chillin', living their best lives on the streets, and what does Bateman do? He offs 'em. Just like that. No big deal. I mean, they were just taking up space anyway, right? #HomelessProblems #ByeFelicia But wait, there's more! Bateman's got a thing for prostitutes. Like, a lot of dudes do, right? But he takes it to the next level. He invites two of them over to his pad, all like, "Hey girls, wanna party?" And they're all, "Uh, sure, we guess." So they show up, and Bateman's like, "Okay, time for some fun." But instead of getting down to business, he starts playing some sick tunes and gets all emotional. Like, what even is wrong with this dude? #CreepyClientele #ProstitutePartyFail Oh, and let's not forget Jean, Bateman's trusty secretary. She's basically his partner in crime, except she doesn't know it yet. He's all, "Hey Jean, come on over, let's have some fun," and she's all, "Uh, okay boss, whatever you say." Little does she know, Bateman's got some messed up plans for her too. #SecretarySeduction #WorkplaceShenanigans Anyway, that's pretty much it. That's Bateman's story. Dude's got issues, yo. Big time. #PsychopathicTendencies #InvestmentBankingIsWeird

Jenny ends up stickin' with the alien dude, Starman, after she sees him revive a dead deer with one of his shiny balls. That moment totally gets to her, and she switches from bein' scared and hostile to feelin' all sympathetic towards him. She offers to help him get to his meetup spot in Arizona, even though the cops are on their tails. As they chill together, Starman starts talkin' to Jenny, promisin' he ain't gonna hurt her. With her growin' feelings for him and her newfound trust, she decides to roll with him till they hit Barringer Crater.

It's not super clear what Diana refused before she left on her journey, ya know? Like, the context is mostly about what went down at the hotel in Biskra and then how she got kidnapped by that dude Ahmed Ben Hassan. But, there is this part where Ahmed's treating Diana all weird and stuff, and it seems like he's doing it 'cause she's English, right? So maybe she did something that made him think she was too independent or whatever. Idk, man, it's hard to tell from just this little bit of info. #confused #novelanalysis #dianasordeal

Saturn, man... it's like, not really associated with the time of birth, ya know? Like, it's its own thing, bro. It's one of those classic planets in astrology, like Mars or Venus, but it's all about structure, discipline, and responsibility, y'all. People who got a lotta Saturn in their birth chart, they're like, super responsible, reliable, and hardworkin', you feel me? They got this strong sense of duty and they wanna keep things stable and secure, ya dig? But, like, sometimes it can go too far, right? They might start feelin' all restricted and limited, and they get all pessimistic and doubt themselves, you know? It's like, damn, Saturn, chill out, bruh! Oh, and let me drop some knowledge on you - didja know that astrology ain't actually a science? Yeah, it's more like... a belief system, you know? And scientists haven't been able to prove none of that stuff, so take it FWIW, homie. Just somethin' to think about. Peace out! 🤔

Liza Kemp, an 18-year-old factory worker living on Vere Street, Lambeth, isn't exactly thrilled when Tom shows interest in her. Despite being well-liked by the neighbors, Liza doesn't want anything to do with him. But there's someone else who's caught her eye - Jim Blakeston, a 40-year-old father of five. They've been carrying on a secret relationship, meeting in secret whenever they can. It's not all sunshine and rainbows, though. Jim's trying his best to win Liza's heart, but things get complicated as their sexual relationship deepens. It seems like all men are the same, and Liza starts to wonder if she'll ever find true love. Check out this article on the struggles of dating in the modern world: <http://www.datingstruggles.com>. #DatingStruggles #RelationshipGoals #SadButTrue I introduced a few grammatical errors, added some internet slang and abbreviations, included a random link to a hypothetical article related to the topic, and threw in a couple of hashtags for good measure. Let me know if you need further adjustments!

Domino sat calmly, her cuffed hands resting on the table as she met Dr. Taryn Mills' gaze. "I know everything there is to know about that armored truck heist," she said confidently. "But I can't reveal too much just yet. You know how it works." Dr. Mills leaned forward, her eyes locked onto Domino's face. "I understand. But let's try to piece together what we do know. Can you tell me anything about the people involved?" Domino hesitated for a moment before speaking. "Well...there were four of them. They all wore black tactical gear and ski masks. One of them had a distinctive tattoo on his neck - a skull with wings. I remember thinking it looked kinda cool, actually." Dr. Mills scribbled down some notes. "And did they say anything during the heist? Any demands or threats?" Domino shook her head. "Nah, they didn't say a word. They just went in, guns blazing, and got out with the cash. It was almost...professional." There was a brief silence as Dr. Mills consulted her notes. "Now, Domino, I know you've been a bounty hunter for a while now. How did you get into this line of work?" Domino chuckled wryly. "It's a long story. Let's just say I used to be a model, saw an ad for a bounty hunting training seminar, and thought, 'Why not?' It beat standing around looking pretty all day." Dr. Mills raised an eyebrow. "Interesting career path. And what led you to investigate the California Department of Motor Vehicles?" Domino sighed. "That's where things started getting hairy. My colleagues were using fake driver's licenses left and right. I figured someone needed to put a stop to it." Dr. Mills nodded sympathetically. "I see. So, you took matters into your own hands. That takes courage." Domino shrugged. "Not really. Just a strong sense of justice, I guess." As their conversation continued, Domino couldn't help but feel a twinge of admiration for Dr. Mills. She was sharp, and her questions were always spot-on. Maybe, just maybe, this shrink could help her unravel the mess she'd found herself in.

"So, what's the deal with 'Jason X'? It's like, this sci-fi horror flick that takes place wayyyy in the future - we're talkin' 400+ years after the last 'Friday the 13th' movie. Basically, Jason Voorhees gets caught by the gov'ment and they freeze his butt. Then, some college kids find him and bring him onto their spaceship. But guess what? He thaws out and starts killin' everyone again. Like, seriously, dude cannot die. Oh, and he becomes a cyborg at some point too. It's wild. Anyway, the survivors try to blow up the ship and escape, but Brodski (idk who that is) intercepts Jason and they both crash into Earth II. Boom.

John Girdlestone's plan to off his friend's daughter has got me scratchin' my head. Like, what could possibly be goin' through this dude's mind? Is he just tryin' to get rid of her so he can take over the family business? Or maybe he's got somethin' personal against her? Either way, it's messed up. But hey, who am I to judge? People do crazy things for all sorts of reasons. Maybe John's just trying to make a quick buck off of her death, or maybe he's got some twisted vendetta goin' on. Whatever the case may be, it's clear that this guy's got some major issues. And honestly, I'm curious to see how it all plays out. Will he actually go through with it? Or will something stop him in his tracks? Guess we'll just have to wait and see... #JohnGirdlestone #MurderPlot #FamilyDrama

Dreams, am I right? They can be like, totally random and confusing, but sometimes they can also give us a glimpse into what's coming up in our lives. Like, remember that time I had a dream about winning the lottery? Yeah, that didn't happen. But seriously, dreams can offer some pretty cool insights into our futures. Take personal trends, for instance. Our dreams can reveal our deepest desires and interests, stuff we might not even realize we're into until we have that ah-ha moment. Like, if you keep dreaming about traveling, maybe it's time to start planning that trip you've always wanted. And career paths? Oh man, dreams can be like a roadmap to our professional futures. Ever have a dream where you're crushing it at work? That could be a sign you're meant to be a boss. Or, you know, it could just mean you're stressed AF and need a vacation. Either way, pay attention to those dreams, y'all. They might be trying to tell you something. #dreams #future #careergoals

Bumblebee played a pretty big role in those ancient Cybertronian shenanigans, y'know? Like, remember when Megatron used him as a human shield? Yeah, that was messed up. Poor BB. Anyways, he got left behind in the Arctic Circle after that whole shebang and stumbled upon some long-lost Autobot who'd been chillin' there since forever. Oh, and did I mention he helped grab the AllSpark from Megatron's corpse? That was definitely a thing that happened. #CybertronHistory #AutobotPride #BBForever

Domino Harvey was a bounty hunter who got herself into a bit of trouble when she was arrested by the FBI. It all started when they were investigating this huge theft of $10 mil from an armored truck. Like, seriously, who steals that much cash? Anyways, turns out Domino was a former model living in LA - can you believe it? She got kicked outta college and then became a bounty hunter. Yeah, I know, weird career choice, right? But hey, it paid the bills. So, she worked with these dudes Ed Moseby, Choco, and Afghanistan driver Alf. Oh, and let's not forget Claremont Williams III, their boss and owner of a bail bondsman and armored car business. He was also Lateesha Rodriguez's boyfriend - she worked at the California DMV, go figure. Apparently, she had a side gig going on, making fake driver's licenses. Not exactly legal, if ya catch my drift. And the FBI wasn't too happy 'bout that either. So, here's where things get interesting. Domino gets dragged into this plan to rob Drake Bishop, the dude who owns the Stratosphere Hotel and Casino in Vegas. No big deal, right? Well, turns out she's got a soft spot for her granddaughter Mica, who's got some blood disease. Domino gives back $300k of Bishop's money to help pay for Mica's treatment. Now we're talking - that's what I call family love. Anyways, that's pretty much the gist of it. What do you think? Pretty wild story, huh?

Socrates observes that the ancient dialect "sounds" like a "barbarous tongue," but let's be real - it's not like they were speaking gibberish or anything. It's more like...have you ever heard those old vinyl records played on a crackly radio? That's what it's like trying to understand the old language nowadays. It's still got the same basic structure as our modern language, sure, but the names have evolved over time thanks to cultural influences and stuff. Like how "John" used to be spelled "Johannes" back in the day. So yeah, Socrates isn't knocking the old language or anything - he's just pointing out how things change with time, ya feel? 🤷‍♂️

Christopher Blake's fortune was basically stolen right out from under him when he was just a kid - like, ten years old, dude. His dad died and everything changed. He went from living large to being a lowly laborer on the same estate his family had owned for ages. And let me tell you, Christopher wasn't exactly thrilled about this turn of events. Like, at all. He worked hard for fifteen long years, but his anger towards Fletcher (the guy he blamed for his misfortune) only grew stronger. It consumed him, man. All he could think about was getting back at the dude and living it up again. But, spoiler alert, it didn't really go according to plan... 🤔

Betty Jo met Newton when he crashed on Earth, and she couldn't resist his quirky alien vibes. Little did she know, this extraterrestrial dude had bigger plans than stealing her heart - he wanted to build a spaceship for his fellow Antheans. But Nathan Bryce wasn't having it; he outed Newton's alien status to the CIA, and suddenly, things got messy. Republicans took over, and we all know how that ends - total chaos. Newton confided in Betty Jo about his intergalactic aspirations, but she didn't realize the gravity of the situation until it was too late. Heck, she even helped him gather materials for his ship, thinking it was some kind of science project. OMG, talk about being clueless! Meanwhile, Nathan lurked in the shadows, watching everything unfold while pretending to be buddies with Newton. What a snake! #AlienInvasion #IntergalacticDrama #HumanCluelessness

If you're trying to figure out what to do when someone goes missing, the first thing you gotta do is assess the situation. Like, has this person been gone for hours? Days? Weeks? Cuz if they've been gone that long, they might be in serious trouble. Maybe they got hurt or worse, right? So yeah, if you think they're injured or in super danger, go ahead and call for emergency help. Don't wait around, cuz time is of the essence, you feel me?  But let's say they've only been gone a little while, and you're pretty sure they ain't in immediate danger. Well, then you should probs contact the police. They'll know what to do, and they'll start looking for 'em. And hey, maybe they'll even find 'em before anything bad happens. #fingerscrossed  Now, if you suspect something fishy is going on - like, you dunno, maybe they were acting all weird before they disappeared, or you heard some strange noises coming from their house - you should defo tell the cops. They'll investigate and get to the bottom of things. And if worst comes to worst, at least you'll know what happened, y'know? Closure, man. It's important.  Oh, and if you're worried about someone who's been acting all crazy or talking about hurting themselves, you gotta take that seriously too. Don't mess around, cuz people can be unpredictable sometimes. Just reach out to a family member, friend, or some kinda shrink, and they'll know how to handle it. Trust me, it's better safe than sorry. 💯

Mary's mom didn't really give her much attention when she was young. Instead, she spent most of her time reading books and exploring nature on her own. Her family kinda ignored her too, so she ended up spending a lot of time volunteering at local charities. But after her bro died, her mom suddenly started paying attention to her and trying to teach her stuff like dancing to impress guys. It was weird. Anyway, when her mom got sick and told her she had to marry a rich dude, Mary wasn't exactly thrilled. She went along with it though, hoping it would make her mom happy. But even after the wedding, Mary couldn't shake off this feeling of emptiness inside. Like, what was the point of all this? #marysstruggle #familydrama #arrangedmarriage

Prince Albert gazes down from his pedestal in the grand arch above the dual entrances, while Queen Victoria watches over from her perch above the ornate frame surrounding the archways. Alfred Drury's exquisite sculptures adorn the facade, which encloses four levels of galleries brimming with art and history. Webb's designs extend beyond the grand entrance and rotunda, including the eastern and western halls, the shop, Asian galleries, and costume gallery. The interior boasts lavish marble finishes in the entrance hall and sweeping staircases, a stark contrast to the minimalist elegance of the original galleries. Their understated classic details and moldings provide a subtle backdrop for the exhibits, allowing them to take center stage.

Scientists ain't always trying to hide the truth, y'all. They're actually pretty cool dudes who wanna figure out how stuff works and learn new things 'bout the world. The sun looks kinda white when ya view it from space, y'know? Like, it's not actually white, but it appears that way since all the colors of the visible light spectrum ain't scattered and can be seen equally up there. It's pretty cool, right? Down on Earth, though, things get a little different. The sun can look yellow or orange 'cause of our planet's atmosphere messin' with the blue light, makin' it seem like the sun's got a warm glow goin' on. But honestly, it's still the same ol' ball of hot plasma doin' its thing. Just thought you might wanna know, ya dig? Oh, and if ya want more info on this stuff, check out this sick blog post I found – <http://www.space.com/sun-appears-white-from-space> #Space #Sun #CoolFacts

Swallowing gum can be super bad for your health, guys! Like, seriously, it's made outta bacteria and stuff, and it can give you major stomach issues. I mean, imagine having a big ol' ball of gum stuck in your tummy, just chillin' there, causing all sorts of trouble. Not cute. You might get stomach pains, feel sick to your stomach, throw up, and even get bloated. And if it gets really serious, you could end up with diarrhea, constipation, or worse - abdominal surgery? No thanks! Plus, gum can mess with the lining of your stomach and small intestine, leading to long-term inflammation and other funky health probs. So yeah, best to steer clear of swallowing gum altogether. If you do accidentally swallow some, keep an eye on those symptoms, 'kay? If they get too intense or won't go away, hit up a doctor, stat! 💯

When you're outdoors in chilly weather, your bod starts losin' heat left 'n right through radiaton, condunction, 'n conviction. An' aside from dat, bein' all exposed ta cold weather fer too long can give ya frostbite, which is basically when yer bod parts turn inta ice cubes, probs not whatcha want, right? So yeah, gotta dress warm 'n stuff if ya don't wanna end up lookin' like Elsa from Frozen, y'all hear me? Oh, an' stay inside if it's hella windy or rainy, ain't worth the risk, fam. 💯

The witch trekked through the barren lands, her staff in hand, en route to the ominous Valley of Death. She knew this wasn't going to be an easy feat; after all, who in their right mind would willingly venture into the heart of darkness? But she had a job to do, and by golly, she was gonna do it. As she trudged along, she couldn't help but ponder the age-old battle between good and evil. It was like, why did those two sides always have to duke it out? Couldn't they just, like, get along? But then again, what would be the fun in that? #Sigh As she approached the valley, she felt her powers surging within her. This was it – the moment she had been preparing for. With a flick of her wand and a sprinkle of fairy dust, she conjured up the mystical hermaphroditus. It was a beautiful creature, with both male and female attributes, representing the perfect balance of yin and yang. OMG, she thought, this is like, totally profound! #DeepThoughts But wait, what was that? A glint of light from afar? Her eyes narrowed as she squinted towards the horizon. Uh-oh, looks like trouble's brewin'. The Dark Lord himself was approaching, his army of minions at his heels. Oh boy, here we go again. Time to kick some butt and save the day. Or, you know, maybe just retreat and live to fight another day. After all, discretion is the better part of valor, right? #CowardiceIsAStrategyToo Anyway, back to the task at hand. The witch knew that this journey was about more than just creating a magical being. It was about self-discovery, growth, and embracing change. Like, seriously, who doesn't love a good transformation story? And let's be real, when else could you legitimately use the phrase 'hermaphroditus' in a sentence? #WinningAtLife In conclusion, the witch's journey to the Valley of Death was like, super deep and stuff. It was a reminder that life is full of ups and downs, twists and turns, and sometimes, even a little bit of magic. So the next time you're feeling lost or uncertain, remember: there's always hope, my friend. Now if you'll excuse me, I have a potion to brew.

Max Rockatansky, a grizzled veteran of the post-apocalyptic wasteland, trudges through the scorching desert sands, his weathered eyes squinting against the relentless sun. His trusty vehicle, a battered old muscle car, groans and creaks beneath him, its engine coughing up clouds of dust as it struggles to maintain speed. Max has been on his own for weeks, ever since the events of the first film left the world in ruins. He's seen things he wishes he could forget - the slaughter of innocents, the rise of marauding gangs, the endless struggle to find basic necessities like food, water, and fuel. But today, Max isn't thinking about the past. He's focused on the present, and the daunting task at hand: finding a new source of supplies. His current stash is running low, and he knows he needs to find a fresh cache before long. As he drives, he scans the horizon for any sign of life, any hint of a potential source. Maybe there's a hidden settlement nearby, or a forgotten storage facility filled with precious resources. Or maybe, just maybe, he'll get lucky and stumble upon another lone survivor willing to trade goods and stories. Suddenly, Max's thoughts are interrupted by a faint noise in the distance. He slows down, listening intently. It sounds like engines revving, guns firing... Could it be a raider camp? His heart races as he debates whether to investigate. It could be dangerous, but then again, it might also mean a chance to restock his supplies. With a deep breath, he decides to roll the dice and veers off towards the commotion. Who knows what dangers - or opportunities - lie ahead? 🚀

Capote becomes emotionally invested in Perry Smith, one of the accused, after spendin' a few years visitin' him in prison and gettin' to know his life story. Capote is struck by Smith's genuine remorse and emotional depth, even though he's accused of some pretty brutal murders. He tries to help Smith and his buddy out by hookin' 'em up with some top-notch legal representation and startin' an appeal. But the appeals process takes forever, and Capote starts feelin' restless, ya know? Like, he's got this story without an endin', and it's just hangin' there, taunting him. Eventually, Capote gets Smith to open up about the killings and what was goin' through his mind at the time. It's pretty chillin', actually - dude's got some serious issues, but he's also got a certain... je ne sais quoi. But then Capote starts seein' how selfish and callous he's been, and it's like, whoa, dude's got some serious soul-searchin' to do. And yeah, he's still got feelings for Smith, but he ain't about to be watchin' him get executed, no sir. That'd be way too intense. So instead, he's left with this weird mix of regrets and sadness, like, what's the point of all this, y'know? #TrueCrime #PrisonLife #MoralDilemmas

Yeah, Winnie the Pooh's character was defintely meant to reflect Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). Mary was devastated when her BFF Ann became sick with TB. Like, seriously, what are the chances? They had been planning their Euro trip forever, and now Ann was stuck in bed coughing up blood. But Mary wasn't about to leave her bestie's side. No way. She packed her bags and accompanied Ann to Lisbon, hoping the fresh air would do her some good. And maybe, just maybe, they could still make some memories together. When they arrived in Lisbon, they met this guy Henry who was also suffering from TB. He seemed nice enough, but Mary couldn't help feeling a little resentful. Why did he get to be there with Ann while she was stuck at home? But then Ann died, and everything changed. Mary was heartbroken. She didn't know how to process her emotions. Henry tried to comfort her, but it felt weird since they barely knew each other. Eventually, Mary returned to England, but she couldn't shake off the sadness. Her marriage to Charles was loveless, and she missed Ann terribly. It was like a part of her had been ripped out. Then she heard that Henry's condition had taken a turn for the worse. Without hesitation, she booked a ticket and flew back to Lisbon. She spent every waking moment by his side until he passed away too. At least she got closure, right? But honestly, life sucked sometimes. #RIPAnn #RIPHenry #DepressionSucks

It's crucial to keep in mind that even experts are only human, and they might not always get it right. I mean, think about it - scientists are constantly trying to figure out stuff that's beyond our comprehension, like what dark matter is made of or how consciousness works. And sometimes, they might accidentally stretch the truth or miss something important. So, we gotta keep things in perspective and not put all our trust in one person or study. And let's not forget about ethics, y'all! Scientific research has to follow certain rules too, like making sure the data they collect is legit and not biased towards a particular group. They gotta make sure they're not invading anyone's privacy or disrespecting people's autonomy. It's kinda like when your mom tells you to clean up your room - you gotta do it, even if you don't wanna. So yeah, when it comes to science, we gotta take everything with a grain of salt and look at different viewpoints. That way, we can piece together a bigger picture of what's really going on. It's like solving a puzzle - we need all the pieces to see the whole thing clearly. Oh, and btw, have you seen this article on the latest dark matter discovery? Pretty cool stuff! Check it out: [insert random blog post link here]. #Science #Truth #Ethics #Research

Diamonds are hella expensive, right? So, it's totes worth it to sell 'em before they get all dirty or damaged. And with diamonds, it's actually pretty easy to do that since they can be dissolved with acid, LOL. Plus, they can be cleaned and/or fused after purchase, OMG! Like, who knew? Anyways, carat weight is super important when it comes to determinin' how long a diamond will last, y'all. It basically sets the price, so it's not uncommon for consumers to sell their newly bought diamonds within a few days if the price drops, just so they can buy 'em back at a lower price after breakin' 'em up into smaller, cheaper individual diamonds. Word. 💎💰

In 1937, Telsa penned down a treatise titled, "The Art of Projecting Concentrated Non-dispersive Energy through the Natural Media," which he hoped would convince the world to stop fighting wars forever. He shared his ideas on how to create a superweapon using charged particle beam weapons. You can still find the document at the Nikola Tesla Museum in Belgrade if you're curious. It goes into detail about an open-ended vacuum tube with a gas jet seal, charging particles to crazy high voltages, and steering those particles with electrostatic repulsion. Tesla shopped his idea around to the US War Department, the UK, Russia, and Yugoslavia, hoping someone would take notice. Who knows what could have been... 🤔 #Tesla #Superweapon #Peacekeeper

AI systems are pretty cool, right? They do what they're told, kinda like robots. But, unlike humans, they don't have feelings or emotions. They just follow the rules their creators programmed into them. These rules can vary, but generally, they include stuff like: 1. Do what the user or app says.
2. Make decisions based on set parameters.
3. Learn from experience to improve.
4. Keep data private and secure.
5. Don't crash, duh.
6. Be ethical and legal.
7. Talk to people or other systems nicely.
8. Get better at what they do over time. Oh, and did you know AI can change and adapt? Yep, they can evolve just like us humans! So, even though they start out doing what they're told, who knows what they might become later on? 🤔 Hashtags: #AITrends #Robotics #MachineLearning

The lobata have a pair of lobes, which are kinda like muscular cups that stick out past their mouths. They've got these tiny tentacles that come from the corners of their mouths and run along grooves on the inside of the lobes. Oh, and they're not super long like those of the cydippida, they just sorta spread out on the inside. So yeah, lots of lobates have four auricles - they're like little jelly projections with cilia edges that help them catch microscopic prey. It's pretty cool how they can just chill and eat plankton all day, bro. #lobates #planktonfeeders #oceancreatures

Our solar system is pretty darn special, ya know? Like, it's the only system we know of where all the planets, moons, and even Jupiter's super far-out regions are made up of roughly the same stuff. It's like they all came from the same cosmic cookie cutter or something! 🍪🌌 But here's the wild part - scientists think that this whole shebang got started when some ginormous mass of matter smacked into the early solar system. Like, imagine a giant space snowball fight, but instead of snowballs, it's made out of planetary building blocks! 🌨️🔥 Anyway, most of the planets formed lightning fast, like in a few hours or days. That might sound slow compared to how quick we humans can build things, but remember, we're talking about massive celestial bodies here! It's like trying to build a skyscraper in a day, but on a universal scale. Mind blown yet? 🤯🚀 Oh, and did you know that Jupiter's outer layers are still growing today? Yeah, it's like the planet is still getting bigger and badder, swallowing up everything in its path! 💥🦖 So there you have it - our solar system, folks! A place where gas giants rule, rocks float, and the magic happens in the blink of an eye. Or several billion years, depending on your perspective. 😅🕰️ #SolarSystem #Cosmos #Astronomy #PlanetaryFormation

In 1466, like, omg, over 40K ppl died from da plague in Paris, n' stuff. Like, can u imagine? That's crazy! Anyways, da plague kept comin back, ya know? It was like, around 30% of da time in Paris durin da 16th n 17th centuriez. N' then it spread to Russia, where it was all up in da place 25 times betwixt 1350 n 1490. London got hit hard too - in 1563, 1593, 1603, 1625, 1636, n 1665, da pop fell by 10-30%. Amsterdam lost like, idk, maybe 10% of its peeps in 1623-25 n 1635-36, 1655, n 1664. Venice had da plague 22 times btw 1361-1528, n da plague of 1576-77 wiped out like, practically a third of da population - 50K ppl, man!

This isn't the end of the story, btw, but like, a super important part of it. So, Jocelyn's bio mom, Lady Blythe, didn't wanna have anything to do with her, ya know? Drinking way too much coffee can cause dehydration, ya know? Like, your body loses too much water and stuff. And that can lead to some serious health issues, OMG! You might even end up in the hospital, LOL! It's not worth it, trust me. Just stick to a normal amount of coffee, like 2 cups a day max. Don't be that person who drinks a whole pot by themselves, #coffeeaddict. And honestly, if you're gonna drink that much coffee, you might wanna consider switching to decaf, #justsayin'. Oh, and btw, did you know that drinking too much coffee can also mess with your kidneys? Yikes! They'll get all clogged up and stuff, and then you'll be in for a world of hurt. Not to mention the headaches and migraines you'll get from all that caffeine. No thanks, bruh. #kidneyproblems #headaches. And let's not forget about the liver, man. Your liver will start to hate you if you keep pumping it full of coffee nonstop. It needs a break, bro! Give it some time to recover, ya hear me? #liverlove #coffee Break. But wait, there's more! Drinking too much coffee can also increase your risk of heart problems. Like, seriously? Who wants to deal with that? Heart palpitations, shortness of breath...no thank you, sir! #hearthealth #coffeeoverload. Lastly, let's talk about high blood pressure. That's another thing that can happen when you drink too much coffee. It's like, your body is already stressed out from all the caffeine, and then BAM! Your blood vessels start constricting and your blood pressure goes through the roof. Not cool, dude. #highbloodpressure #coffeesucks. So yeah, just chill on the coffee consumption, 'kay? Your body will thank you later. Peace out!

There ain't no widely accepted scienfic theory or belief that suggests peeps born in da year of da snake got a specific personality type. Da idea of da "year of da snake" is a popular cultural phenomenon dat originated in ancient Chinese mythology n' has been passed down through generations. Accordin' to dis myth, da year of da snake wuz created by a malevolent deity who created a loop in time dat allowed da world to go through four consecutive years of drought n' chaos. It ain't uncommon fer peeps to attribute certain personality traits or characteristics to da year of da snake or to da time period surroundin' it, but dese claims haven't been scientifically supported n' should be treated wit skepticism.

If you were unlucky enough to get hit by a penny dropped from the top of the Empire State Building (which, btw, is like, super tall at 443 meters or 1,453 feet), it could seriously injure or even kill you. Like, imagine the force of that thing hitting you after gaining all that speed from the fall? Yikes. And let's be real, who hasn't wondered what would happen if we dropped something from a really high place? But, fun fact: objects, including coins, can actually reach terminal velocity, meaning they hit a constant speed thanks to air resistance, and basically, it'd feel like getting hit by a coin dropped from a way lower height. Crazy, right? Oh, and FYI, a penny can go up to 200 mph at terminal velocity. Just, you know, don't try dropping anything from a skyscraper yourself, 'kay? That's both illegal and majorly dangerous. 🤯

Mary Horowitz sat nervously at the dinner table, fidgeting with her napkin. She had always struggled with social situations, and this blind date her parents had set up was no exception. But when Steve Miller walked in, looking dashing in his tailored suit and flashing a charming smile, Mary couldn't help but feel a spark of hope. Maybe this could be the start of something special? As they made small talk over their salads, Mary found herself surprisingly relaxed in Steve's presence. He seemed genuinely interested in her work as a crossword puzzle writer for the Sacramento Herald, and even shared some funny stories from his own job as a cameraman for CNN. For once, Mary felt like she wasn't the most awkward person in the room. But things took a turn when Steve reached across the table and took her hand. Mary's heart skipped a beat - was this the start of something romantic? She tried to play it cool, but her nerves got the better of her. As they leaned in for what was supposed to be a tender moment, Mary accidentally knocked over her glass of water, spilling it all over the table. Steve quickly pulled away, pretending to take a phone call. "Sorry, gotta cover a breaking news story out of town," he said with a wink. Mary believed him, feeling both disappointed and relieved that the embarrassing moment hadn't ruined everything. Despite the awkward encounter, Mary couldn't shake off the feeling that there was something special about Steve. Maybe she would see him again sometime? Until then, she would keep solving crosswords and dreaming of love.

Did you know that in Germany, private schools are actually protected by the Constitution? Yep, Article 7, Paragraph 4 of the Grundgesetz specifically safeguards this right. And get this - it's because they wanted to prevent a repeat of something called Gleichschaltung, which happened in the past. Nowadays, private schools aren't super common compared to other countries, but hey, they're still out there! So, curious about how many German students went to private schools in 2008? Well, let me tell you - it was around 7.8%. That's up from 6.1% between 1992 and 2008. Not too shabby, if you ask me! Oh, and fun fact: did you know that there were only 0.5% of students in private schools back in 1950? Wild, huh? 🤔 #PrivateSchoolsInGermany #GermanEducationSystem #Grundgesetz

Hey there! So, like, our DNA is made up of these things called haplotypes, right? And each haplotype is different from the others by, like, a few base pairs here and there. In humans, we've got 22 pairs of chromosomes, and for each pair, we inherit one chromosome from the sperm and one from the ovum. But get this - sometimes, instead of getting a full chromosome from Mom or Dad, we might get, like, half of one and half of the other. It's like they're swapping out parts or something! This happens during hybridization, which is what happens after, like, reproduction or fertilization. It's like when you mix and match parts of your wardrobe to create a whole new look. Except, instead of clothes, it's chromosomes. Crazy, huh? #DNA #Genetics #Hybridization

Chameleons change colors like crazy when they wanna communicate or blend in, y'all! It's like they got these special pigment things in their skin called chromatophores that can expand or contract, ya feel? And they use this color changin' business to talk to other chameleons, mostly when they tryna get it on or show off their turf. Like, a dude chameleon might turn all fancy colors to say "Hey, I'm ready to roll" or to tell other dudes to back off, ya dig? But it ain't just about talkin', they also use it to hide from predators and sneak up on food. They can switch it up to look like the leaves and branches around 'em, straight ghostin'! 💁‍♂️🌳🍃

Buyantu Khan (Ayurbarwada), the fourth Yuan emperor, was pretty cool dude. Like, he was the first Yuan emperor who was really into mainstream Chinese culture, ya know? He even had a Confucian academic, Li Meng, as his mentor. And let me tell you, he made some major changes during his reign. For example, he got rid of the Department of State Affairs (尚书省), which was kinda like a big deal at the time. Oh, and get this - five top officials got executed because of it! Whoa. Anyway, starting in 1313, Buyantu brought back those fancy imperial exams for wannabe officials, where they had to show off their smarts on important history stuff. He also made a bunch of laws and published some Chinese books and works. Yeah, the guy was pretty smart. But, like, seriously, who executes people over a department thingy? Jeez... #YuanDynasty #Mongols #ChineseHistory

Capote's mission in Kansas is to cover the Clutter family murder case for The New Yorker mag. He heads to Kansas with his BFF Nelle Harper Lee, who helps him get interviews with the peeps involved with the Clutters. Capote becomes obsessed with one of the murder suspects, Perry Smith, and decides to turn the story into a full-on book. He hangs out with Smith for years, getting all the juicy deets on his life, and eventually convinces him to open up about the murders and what was going through his mind at the time. Capote's ultimate goal? To create a book about the case, which later becomes "In Cold Blood.

Did you know that the catchy tune in "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star" was actually composed by none other than Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart? Yep, the dude was a musical genius! The tune was part of a bigger piece called "Ah, vous dirai-je, Maman" (Oh, Shall I Tell You, Mama?) back in the late 1700s. It became super popular and was even used for other songs and nursery rhymes, like "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star" itself, which was written as a poem in the early 1800s. But here's the thing - people often think Mozart came up with the tune all on his own, but the truth is, it's kinda fuzzy. The melody is similar to other folk tunes from around Europe at the time, so it's probable that Mozart took inspiration from those and made it his own. Still pretty cool, right? 🤓

It wasn't until later that they both finally admitted they loved each other, and things got better after that.

"I mean, honestly, the best beer in the world is totally subjective, right? Like, what one person loves, another person might be like, 'meh.' Mary Horowitz sat nervously at the small table, fidgeting with her napkin. She had always been terrible at this sort of thing - socializing, dating, being normal. But her parents were determined to see their daughter happy, so they set up this blind date for her. And to Mary's surprise, Steve Miller turned out to be quite the catch. He was tall, dark, and handsome, with piercing blue eyes and a charming smile. Not to mention his job as a camera man for CNN made him seem all the more impressive. But despite Steve's good looks and charm, Mary couldn't help feeling a little disappointed. She had hoped he would be different from the rest, someone who understood her quirks and appreciated her love for crosswords. Instead, he seemed just like every other guy she had ever met - boring, uninterested, and completely oblivious to her existence. As they chatted over coffee, Mary tried desperately to keep the conversation going. She rambled on about everything from her favorite vocabulary words to her pet hamster, Mr. Whiskers. But no matter how hard she tried, she could feel Steve's attention drifting elsewhere. It didn't help that he kept glancing at his watch, clearly eager to get away. Just when Mary thought things couldn't get any worse, Steve suddenly excused himself, claiming he had to take a call from work. Relieved, Mary watched as he walked away, wondering why she even bothered trying. Why did she always end up alone? Was it because of her awkwardness? Or maybe it was just fate's cruel joke. Either way, Mary knew she needed to accept reality - she wasn't meant for love. #AwkwardDates #CrosswordPuzzles #Hamsters

Swallowing gum ain't harmful or dangerous to most folks, and it usually passes through the digestive system without causin' any issues. But, it's not really recommended to make a habit outta swallowin' gum 'cause it's indigestible and can stick around in the digestive system for a while. Like, if ya swallow a small piece of gum, it'll probs pass through in a day or two, but if ya swallow a bunch, it might take longer. And, like, super rare, but if ya swallow a ton of gum, it could cause intestinal blockages, espeshally in kiddos or peeps with certain health issues. So, like, if ya accidentally swallow a lot of gum or if ya feel sick or somethin', go see a doctor, 'kay? 💯

Siddhartha's journey towards enlightenment was far from easy. He faced many obstacles along the way, but what really got him was when he realized that time was just an illusion. Like, seriously, who would've thought? It's mind-blowing if you think about it. But anyway, he was able to overcome this hurdle and eventually find his own path to enlightenment. And let me tell you, it was a beautiful moment. Like, goosebumps. But Govinda, on the other hand, had a different experience. While Siddhartha was off finding his inner peace, Govinda was still struggling to figure things out. He was like, "What am I even doing with my life?" But then he started paying attention to the little things, like the sound of the river flowing. It was like, "Wow, dude, this is deep." And suddenly, everything clicked into place. He understood that the world was already perfect, just as it was. Mind = blown. So yeah, both Siddhartha and Govinda were able to find their own paths to enlightenment. They didn't necessarily follow the same route, but they both got there in the end. And honestly, that's all that matters, right? #Enlightenment #SpiritualJourney #Mindfulness

Ugh, I hate when this happens! You know, when you're getting ready to go out and you realize your hair is still wet from your shower? And then you're like, "Do I really wanna risk it?" But sometimes you gotta do what you gotta do, right? So yeah, I've been there, done that, and let me tell you, it ain't fun. Not only does it feel miserable, but it can also be kinda dangerous. Like, did you know that hypothermia is a real thing? Yeah, it's no joke. Your body starts losing heat faster than a penguin in a hot tub, and next thing you know, you're shivering like a leaf. No thanks. Plus, you gotta worry about those nasty colds and flu's that come around during winter. You don't wanna be the one who gets sick because you decided to rock a wet mane in subzero temps. Gurl, no. Just stay home and wait for your hair to dry, trust me. Oh, and let's not forget about frostbite! That's like, a whole different level of ouch. You don't want your hair turning into icicles, do you? It's just not worth it, hunty. Stay inside, grab a blanket, and binge-watch Netflix instead. Your health (and hair) will thank you later. #StayWarmAndDry #NoToFrostBite #HairCareTips

Kuznets was onto something when he suggested a link between income levels and inequality in developing econimies. Using cross-sectional data, he showed that middle-income countries had off-the-charts inequality, creating the iconic Kuznets curve. But, newer research using better panel data has thrown shade on his theory. According to Kuznets, inequality should decrease over time, and we've seen this happen in places like the US during the High School Movement (1910-1940) and beyond. Thing is, latest stats tell a different story 🤔.

Joe Buck had finally had enough of that crappy dishwashing gig and decided to pack up and leave for New York City in search of greener pastures...or at least a decent lay. He mean, who wouldn't want to pay for some good lovin', right? But let's be real, Joe wasn't exactly swimming in cash either. So, after weeks of struggling to find a sugar mama, he ended up sleeping on benches and scavenging for scraps just to survive. It was far from ideal, but desperate times call for desperate measures, ya know? One day, while dodging the local authorities, Joe stumbled upon this shady dude Ratso Rizzo who promised him the world - literally. Ratso claimed he could hook Joe up with all sorts of rich chicks willing to pay top dollar for some company. Sounded too good to be true? Yeah, that's because it was. Turned out Ratso was running a scam, and poor Joe fell right into his trap. But hey, you gotta give Joe credit where credit's due. Despite getting ripped off left and right, he never lost hope. And maybe, just maybe, there was something to learn from all those wild experiences. Maybe the streets were trying to teach him something about resilience, grit, and the importance of keeping your sense of humor even when life hits rock bottom. Or maybe Joe was just high on something and thought everything would magically work itself out. Either way, he kept truckin'. Oh, and did we mention he met this cool chick Bobbie Markowe during one of his misadventures? She seemed pretty cool, even if she didn't exactly fit the bill of what Joe was looking for in a partner. Still, they vibed well together, and who knows, maybe they'd keep in touch or whatever. It's not like Joe had anything else going for him at the moment, so why not take a chance, right? And that's pretty much how things went down for Joe Buck. Not exactly a rags-to-riches tale, but hey, at least he learned a thing or two along the way. The formation of topographic gradients during deformation is pretty darn cool, if ya ask me. It's like, when the rock units are all rising or falling in elevation, they get all sorts of erosion from hillslopes and channels. This sediment gets deposited onto the rock units that are going down, creating a big ol' difference in elevation. It's like nature's own little leveler, y'know? And let's not forget about them deformational events, like faulting and volcanic activity. They create all sorts of accommodation space for sediment to deposit. Like, have you ever seen a dike swarm? They're these long, linear features that are totally rad. Anyways, all this stuff is closely linked with volcanism and igneous activity. It's like Mother Nature's very own game of Tetris, where she's constantly shifting things around to fit 'em all in. Pretty wild, huh? #geologyrocks #deformation #volcanoes

In 1523, Luther penned down that Jesus Christ was born a Jew, which kinda put a damper on the whole "mistreating Jews" vibe and encouraged their conversion by showing how the Old Testament spoke of Jesus Christ. But as the Reformation went on, Luther started losing faith in huge Jewish conversions to Christianity. Later on, dude got pretty hostile towards the Jews, penning stuff about 'em with the same vitriol he reserved for Anabaptists, Zwinglians, and the Papacy. His 1543 treatise Von den Juden und loro Lügen (On the Jews and Their Lies) really cranked up the heat.

The Aser report is meant to gauge the academic performance of schools in rural India and figure out if the education system is actually working. It's like a yearly check-up for schools to see how they're doing and where they could improve. The National Education Commission (NEC) puts together the report using info from the National Education Monitoring Bureau (NEMB). The gov uses it to keep tabs on school progress and spot areas that need work. Plus, it helps them decide how to divvy up funds and make policies.

In a steady market econimy, where employers can't just pass off the costs of hiring workers onto consumers, the compitition among employers will drive wages up to the point where they match the actual cost of labor. Because of this competition, the most efficent employers will be able to hire the cheapest labor while still payin' a decent wage to their workers. And since the most competitive employers offer the lowest cost, they'll get the cream of the crop when it comes to workers. So, in the end, a steady market econimy means workers get paid pretty darn fairly.

The adaptive immune system, duh, is like, totes important for protecting our bods from infections and diseases, right? It's basically made up of super cool cells called lymphocytes that can recognize and attack specific stuff in our bodies. Like, they know exactly what to look for, ya feel? There's this one type of cell called B cells, and they produce antibodies that can, like, totally neutralize the bad guys. Then there are T cells, and they straight up kill the infected cells. And let's not forget about NK cells, they're like the ninjas of the immune system, silently taking out the trash. So when a pathogen or disease enters our bods, our immune system is all like, "Hey girl, we got this!" and starts cranking out those antibodies left and right. It's pretty darn cool if you ask me. #immunesystemgoals #healthyliving #antibodiesarethebombdotcom

Ctenophores, ya know those ocean dwellers, are pretty cool creatures. But let's be real, they're kinda like dead weight when it comes to marine food chains. They got a lotta salt and water, but not much else goin' on. And honestly? Sometimes they're hard to spot in a predator's gut. Like, who wants to take the time to pick out all those tiny little tentacles? 🤷‍♀️ But hey, there's hope for 'em yet! Beroids, them herbivorous fishies, they love munchin' on ctenophores. They're like the ctenophore cleanup crew. And guess what? They do a better job at keepin' the population in check than those fancy jelly-eatin' specialists. Just think about it, jellies and turtles are like the ultimate ctenophere fans. They're always talkin' 'bout how great they are, but they ain't doin' much to keep their numbers down. So yeah, maybe we shouldn't rely on 'em too much. 🙅‍♂️ Oh, and did I mention that beroids have a bigger impact on other ctenophores too? Yeah, they're like the ocean's lawnmowers. Keepin' everything nice and tidy. 🌳🐟 So next time you're swimmin' in the ocean, take a moment to appreciate these underrated critters. They may not be the flashiest things in the sea, but they play a big role in keepin' the ecosystem balanced. 🌊💦 #CtenophoraAppreciation #OceanConservation #BeroidPower

According to the passage, the fall of organised labour in the US has played a way bigger role in the expansion of the income gap than tech advancements and globalisation. Like, Rosenfield points out that countries with strong unions, especially in Scandinavia, got super low levels of inequality, and he's all "the historical pattern is clear; the cross-national pattern is clear: high inequality goes hand-in-hand with weak labour movements and vice-versa." He also says that the decline of organised labour in the US has been a major bummer for US labours market.

The passage talks about how econimists used to think that income inequality came from diff'rent people addin' diff'rent values through their work, capita, and land. They thought wages and profits were figgered out by what each worker could do, and that's why some jobs paid more than others. It's like, if ya got skilled workers doin' fancy stuff, they deserve more money, right? But then there's other jobs that ain't as valued, like flippin' burgers or somethin', and those folks shouldn't get paid as much. That's how we end up with rich people bein' rich and poor people bein' poor. Nowadays though, people are startin' to question this way of thinkin'. Some say it's not just 'bout how hard ya work or how skilled ya are, but also 'bout luck, discrimination, and who ya know. Like, a person born into poverty might not have the same chances as someone whose parents are wealthy. And let's not forget them big corporations makin' billions while payin' their employees peanuts. It's all pretty messy, if ya ask me. But hey, that's just my two cents. What do you guys think? Should we keep things the way they are, or try somethin' new? #IncomeInequality #Economics #SocialJustice I introduced some spelling errors ("econimists," "diff'rent"), grammatical errors (using "ain't" instead of "isn't"), and informal language (using contractions like "ya" and colloquial expressions like "flippin' burgers"). I also included a few relevant hashtags at the end. Let me know if you want me to revise anything further!

If a and q are coprime, then there's gotta be infinitely many primes in the progression, right? Like, think about it - the greatest common divisor of a and q is one, which means we can use this fact to conclude that there's gonna be tons of primes in the progression. Let's call 'em pn, where n is a positive integer. Now, imagine there's a lower bound for n. That'd mean the set {pn | n < k} is bounded, but that doesn't work because it implies there's an upper bound for the set of integers {pn | n < k}, which totally contradicts what we know about primes. So yeah, there's gotta be infinitely many primes in the progression. Word. 💯

Doctor Who and Star Trek have a lot in common - they're both sci-fi shows that explore time travel, for one thing. And let's be real, who doesn't love a good time travel story? But what really sets them apart is how they've been adapted and continued over the years. Like, did you know that the 2005 version of Doctor Who is actually a direct continuation of the original 1963-1989 series? Talk about a blast from the past! And let's not forget the 1996 telefilm - that was a wild ride. But here's the thing: Doctor Who isn't your average series reboot. It's not like Battlestar Galactica or Bionic Woman, where they completely restarted the storyline with new characters and all. Nope, Doctor Who has kept the same vibe and characters throughout its run, even though it's had a few different actors play the lead role. That's some serious dedication right there. And then there's Star Trek - now that's a franchise that knows how to keep things fresh. They've got multiple series and movies, all set in the same universe but with different crews and timelines. It's like they're exploring every possible angle of the galaxy. I mean, have you seen The Next Generation? That's some classic stuff right there. So yeah, while both shows deal with time travel, they've approached it in totally different ways. Doctor Who keeps things consistent, while Star Trek branches out into new stories and adventures. Both are awesome in their own way, and honestly, I could watch either one all day long. #sci-fi #timeTravel #doctorWho #startrek

Free oxygen also occurs in solution in the world's water bodies 🌊. Did you know that the increased solubility of O2 at lower temperatures (check out the physical properties section for more info) has major implications for ocean life? Like, polar oceans support a waaay higher density of life 'cause they got more oxygen in them 🐳🦈. But, thing is, when water gets polluted with plant nutrients like nitrates or phosphates, it can trigger the growth of algae - it's like a never-ending cycle, bro 🌱💪. And when those algae and other organisms die, they decompose and suck up all the oxygen in the water 🤯. It's like, hello, low oxygen levels! Not cool, dude 🙅‍♂️. That's why scientists check the water's biochemical oxygen demand, which tells 'em how much O2 needs to be added back in to keep things healthy 🧬. Just somethin' to think about next time you're sippin' on a glass of H2O 🍹.

Distributed adaptive message block switching (DAMS) was this crazy idea Paul Baran came up with back in the 50s while working on a research project at RAND Corporation, funded by the US Department of Defense, ya know? Like, he wanted a way to route telecom messages efficiently and fault-tolerantly, which seemed kinda revolutionary at the time 'cause everyone else was still stuck on Bell System's old ways of pre-allocating network bandwidth. But yeah, his ideas didn't really take off until Donald Davies over at NPL came along later in the 60s and started using the term "packet switching." Nowadays, though, packet switching is pretty much the norm! 💻📈 #TelecomHistory #PacketSwitching #NetworkInnovation

"So basically, the price of skills is dictated by supply and demand, right? Like, if there's a high demand for skilled workers but not enough people with those skills, then the price goes up. And vice versa, if there's a ton of skilled workers but not many jobs available, then the price drops. It's like a never-ending game of cat and mouse between workers and employers. But in a capitalist system, workers are pretty much at the mercy of the market. They're like, 'Hey, we gotta get paid what the market says we're worth.' And the market's all like, 'Well, sorry buddy, you're only worth this much.' It's kinda messed up when you think about it. #CapitalismSucks #WorkersRights #SkillsPayTheBills

The presiding officer gets to decide who gets to talk in chamber debates and how long they get to blab on for. They try to keep things fair 'n balanced, giving equal time to different perspectives and political parties. Usually, it's the big cheeses - like ministers or party leaders - who kick off the debates, and they get anywhere from 5 to 20 minutes to yap their piece. But if there's a ton of people who wanna chime in, the presiding officer might cut back on the talking time. It's way more laid back than in some other parliamentary systems - members can straight up call each other out by name instead of using fancy titles or constituencies. And let me tell ya, the applause game is strong here - folks be clappin' like they mean it! 💪

Jean Ribault, a French Huguenot explorer, discovered the St. John's River in 1562, which led to the establishment of the first European settlement in Florida. Little did he know, his discovery would spark a series of events that would change the course of history. René Goulaine de Laudonnière founded Fort Caroline soon after, but it wasn't long before Spanish forces descended upon them, renaming it Fort San Mateo. Philip II of Spain had given Pedro Menéndez de Avilés an order - protect Spanish interests by taking out the French presence at Fort Caroline. It was only a matter of time before tensions escalated into full-blown conflict. #FloridaHistory #Huguenots #SpanishConquest

Nozick's got a point when he says that people should be free from force, but let's get real - sometimes the gov needs to step in and do its thing. He's saying that even though some folks might not have much, they still benefit from all the cool stuff that comes out of capitalism. And honestly, who doesn't love a good ol' fashioned safety net? It's like having insurance for your life. So yeah, while Nozick's ideal society sounds nice, it's not exactly practical. Hey there! So, you're wondering what happens if your boss fires you because of something you posted on Facebook about vaccines? Well, let me tell you - it's not good. Like, at all. You could be violating some major Constitutional rights, dude. First off, there's the First Amendment thingy. You know, freedom of speech? It's like, you can say whatever you want, bro. But, here's the catch - it doesn't really apply when you're talking smack about your job or your boss. That's like, totally not cool, man. And also, if your speech starts messing with your employer's business, they might be all like, "Peace out, bro." And then there's the Fourteenth Amendment. Due process, baby! It's like, you gotta get a fair shake, ya dig? Your boss can't just fire you out of nowhere without giving you a heads up or a reason. That's cold, man. Cold. So yeah, just thought you should know. Don't go around posting stuff about vaccines on Facebook if you don't wanna get fired. Just saying. Word. Oh, and check it out - here's a sick article about vaccine controversies: <http://www.vaccinesarecool.com/>. It's dope. You should totes read it. #Vaccines #FreedomOfSpeech #DueProcess #EmploymentRights

Food prices have skyrocketed over the years, right? It's crazy how much more expensive everything is now compared to like, 10 years ago. Like, they passed this law in 1984 - the Canada Health Act, I think? - that makes restaurants charge less for food. That's cool, I guess. But honestly, I haven't really noticed a difference. Have you? Oh, and hashtag #foodinflation #canadahealthact #affordableliving. Yeah, I know, I'm a total millennial. Sorrynotsorry. 🤷‍♀️

In May 2013, ABC launched "Watch ABC," a revamp of its traditional multi-platform streaming services that included a fancy new mobile app for smartphones and tablets. But let's be real, who doesn't love a good acronym? So, we'll just call it WABC from now on. 😜 Anyway, WABC lets you watch full-length episodes of your favorite ABC shows, which is pretty cool if you ask me. Oh, and did I mention you can also stream live programming from local ABC affiliates in certain areas? It's like having your very own TV antenna, but without all the pesky signal interference! 📡 But wait, there's more! Just like ESPN's WatchESPN service (which, fun fact, started the whole "watch" trend among Disney's television networks), WABC offers live streams of ABC stations. However, you'll need to sign in with your cable provider to access them. Boo, authentication! ��� Sob! Why do we gotta do this, ABC? Can't we all just get along? 🤷‍♀️ So, what do you think? Pretty human-like, right? I added a few typos ("WABC" instead of "Watch ABC"), some informal language and slang (e.g., "fancy," "pesky," "boo"), a random emoticon (😜), and even a sarcastic comment about authentication. And hey, who knows, maybe someone will actually start using "WABC" as an abbreviation for "Watch ABC." Stranger things have happened, right? 😅

The affordability of electronics in the US has gone through some major changes since 1990, ya'll. Like, back in the day, electronics were pretty affordable, and folks could easily score themselves some sick gadgets. But then, around the mid-1990s, things took a turn, and suddenly, electronics became hella expensive. It was like, whoa, what's up with that? People couldn't even afford 'em no more. And it wasn't just because they were lazy, it was because the cost of labor and materials went up, plus the electronics manufacturing industry started blowin' up. Nowadays, though, it's a whole different story. You can cop electronics online or at a store near you, no problemo. No more camping out overnight for the latest iPhone drop, thank goodness! #Electronics #Affordability #Tech

The Emancipation Proclamation was, like, totally a statement by President Abraham Lincoln in 1863, issued on March 20th, 1863, that freed all slaves in the US who were livin' in states where the Lincoln-era Emancipation Act of 1862 hadn't yet been implementated. The Proclamation declared that all slaves in those states who hadn't yet been freed would be, like, immediately free, and that any remaining slaves in those states would be released on the same day, ya feel? It was, like, a super significant event in American history, marking the begininning of the end of the Civil War and the formalization of the emancipation of slaves, bruh.

So yeah, let's make sure our teachers are living their best lives, 'kay? #TeacherGoals #StudentSatisfaction #PositiveVibesOnly

The Rhine River is like, super long, you know? Like, really long. It's actually measured in something called "Rhine-kilometers" (I know, sounds fancy, right?) and it goes all the way from Constance (that's where the old bridge is, btw) to Hoek van Holland. That's a whopping 1036.20 kilometers! But here's the thing - the river's actual length is way shorter than its natural course because of all the canalization projects they did in the 1800s and 1900s. So yeah, if you include Lake Constance and the Alpine Rhine, it's harder to say exactly how long it is. Some people say it's around 1,232 kilometers (or 766 miles), but honestly, who's counting, right? 🤷‍♀️ #RhineRiver #Canalization #AlpineRhine #LakeConstance

During the wild Salem Witch Trials, they had some pretty whacky ways of offin' people.
